awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Three Dimensional Raman Imaging System for the Integrated Science Center of SUNY Geneseo
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to SUNY Geneseo is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs to support and improve research by Professor Kazushige Yokoyama and colleagues Jani Lewis, Dori Farthing, Nicholas Warner and Rabeka Alam. This institution is acquiring a three-dimensional Raman imaging system. In general, a Raman microscope begins with a standard optical microscope but then uses a laser to scan the surface of a sample to implement a chemical image over the whole field of view. The laser wavelengths probe the surface and produce a spectrum which identifies chemical components in the material. This gives useful information on the properties of the components. This is a powerful analytical tool for identifying chemical composition qualitatively and semi-quantitatively of various materials. It is being used in several important research areas. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate students in chemistry, biochemistry and geology at this Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) as well as St John Fisher College. The instrumentation provides direct research experience for students in a variety of courses distributed in various departments and other neighboring universities.

The award of this Raman imaging system is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. The science enabled by this instrument provides relevant societal benefits by directly characterizing protein folding over a nanoscale metal interface to detect peptide, self-assembly, delivery, or molecular motor for RNA packaging and by identifying morphologically similar but chemically different proteins at a cellular junction. The instrumentation is also used for characterizing the devitrification process in metallurgical slag to understand potential environmental impacts of slag disposal and for characterizing Mars analogue materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
• The Raman Imaging system installed at SUNY Geneseo advanced research in the following areas: 1) chemistry – direct characterization of a networking or protein folding over a nanoscale metal interface will give insight into a peptide aggregation process (Fig. 1), monitoring of  reversible self-assembly (Fig. 2), investigation of conformational change and interaction of a spike-protein of SARS-CoV-2 (Fig. 3), and the application to nano-probe of the early stage of the Alzheimer’s disease (Fig. 4); 2) biology - identifying three morphologically similar but chemically different proteins at a cellular junction will aid in the diagnosis of the vulvar cancer (Fig. 5); and 3) geological sciences - characterizing the devitrification process in metallurgical rock in Colombia will contribute our understanding of the potential thermal environmental impacts confirming geo-thermometry methodology by Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 6). It contributed to our understanding of the role of water in shaping the landscape, with implications for past habitability.
  • The state-of-the-art instrument located in SUNY Geneseo's Integrated Science Center created collaborative efforts, mentoring opportunities, and hands-on undergraduate research training. It is accessible to a diverse spectrum of researchers, including five whose laboratories are located in the Integrated Science Center, and their 20 undergraduate student research assistants. The proposed system created new curricula for 35 students in the advanced laboratory sections at Geneseo in the areas of chemistry, geological sciences, and biology. Geneseo became the only institution in the Rochester region possessing a Raman Imaging System with the highest capability available in the current market. The instrument’s interdisciplinary applications enabled collaborative efforts and enriched the quality of SUNY Geneseo’s academic programs. It further enhanced the education of our highly accomplished graduates, many of whom go on to medical school or doctoral programs. The project strengthened the research intensity in the region and thus contributed to the advancement of research, development, and leadership of the nation.
  • During the project period, 15 presentations were made by undergraduate students at local and national meetings. There were five publications made involving the undergraduate students as co-authors. As significant outreaches, the PI presented two webinars which were open to the public, and PI and Co-PI were involved in creating YouTube video on the Raman Imaging System available at SUNY Geneseo.
